slidelink.displaytext: Can you uncover your customer’s problems?
Can you clarify your customer’s needs?

search.slidetext: click next to continue.
2 applying vsan solutions in a sales opportunity estimated time to complete: 30 minutes

can you uncover your customer’s problems? meeting in progress… you are talking with your contacts—anja, vi admin, and chinh, vp of infrastructure. based on your target persona chart, you know that the vi admin is the person most familiar with their virtualized environment, while the vp of infrastructure is probably familiar with the sddc and hci. continue continue continue continue continue continue vp of infrastructure vi admin

can you uncover your customer’s problems? which of the following statements best captures this customer’s problem? ? submit submit submit submit submit submit we know that it’s because our storage hasn’t kept up with our workloads, and we’re far behind now. inefficient desktop deployment inefficient desktop deployment inefficient desktop deployment inefficient desktop deployment inefficient desktop deployment inefficient desktop deployment slow overall performance slow overall performance slow overall performance slow overall performance slow overall performance slow overall performance difficulty managing remote users difficulty managing remote users difficulty managing remote users difficulty managing remote users difficulty managing remote users difficulty managing remote users i’m completely confident that the current performance of our storage will be a disaster. can you believe that it sometimes takes users more than 30 minutes to run simple one page reports? what is your confidence in the current performance of your storage for virtualized application needs? you ask: vp of infrastructure vi admin there is probably some degree of inefficiency in the customer’s environment, but the vi admin is complaining more about the effects of an overburdened storage infrastructure. try again try again try again try again try again although the remote users are certainly having difficulties with the system, managing these users isn’t the issue. try again try again try again try again try again yes, the vi admin is specifically focusing on the slow performance of their infrastructure, and they have identified storage as the problem. continue continue continue continue continue

can you uncover your customer’s problems? which of the following statements best captures this customer’s problem? ? submit submit submit submit submit submit yes. we have a team of specialized storage experts, but we really could put their skills to good use elsewhere if storage wasn’t so complicated to maintain and support. complexity of traditional infrastructure complexity of traditional infrastructure complexity of traditional infrastructure complexity of traditional infrastructure complexity of traditional infrastructure complexity of traditional infrastructure lack of employees with specialized skillsets lack of employees with specialized skillsets lack of employees with specialized skillsets lack of employees with specialized skillsets lack of employees with specialized skillsets lack of employees with specialized skillsets inefficiency of storage management inefficiency of storage management inefficiency of storage management inefficiency of storage management inefficiency of storage management inefficiency of storage management is storage management in your organization overly reliant on employees with a specialized skillset that is hard to replace? you ask: vp of infrastructure vi admin yes, the complexity of traditional infrastructure is what forces companies to require specialized skillsets in storage in order to manage their infrastructure. continue continue continue continue continue at this point, we don’t know whether the customer’s storage management is efficient or not; they are complaining about their overdependence on their one storage expert for all their storage management. try again try again try again try again try again more employees with specialized skillsets would help this customer, but the ideal situation would be to avoid the complexity that produces the need for specialized skillsets. try again try again try again try again try again

can you uncover your customer’s problems? which of the following statements best captures this customer’s problem? ? submit submit submit submit submit submit the cost of keeping up with data growth using traditional infrastructure has become too prohibitive. difficulty managing day-to-day storage operations difficulty managing day-to-day storage operations difficulty managing day-to-day storage operations difficulty managing day-to-day storage operations difficulty managing day-to-day storage operations difficulty managing day-to-day storage operations difficulty controlling storage growth difficulty controlling storage growth difficulty controlling storage growth difficulty controlling storage growth difficulty controlling storage growth difficulty controlling storage growth difficulty controlling storage costs difficulty controlling storage costs difficulty controlling storage costs difficulty controlling storage costs difficulty controlling storage costs difficulty controlling storage costs yes, we have outdated infrastructure that needs to be replaced, and we’re opening another manufacturing plant. do you have problems controlling storage costs and planning for growing data capacity demands? you ask: vp of infrastructure vi admin although this customer may have difficulty with storage operations, that isn’t the problem being expressed here. try again try again try again try again try again yes, the essence of the customer’s difficulty is the problem of controlling storage costs. they have growing storage needs that they are unable to meet with traditional infrastructure, due to cost. continue continue continue continue continue this customer is having difficulty with storage growth, but the essence of their complaint isn’t so much the storage growth itself but the expense involved. try again try again try again try again try again

here are the three problems you uncovered for this customer: problem 1: slow overall performance problem 2: complexity of traditional infrastructure problem 3: difficulty controlling storage costs now, it’s time to clarify their needs. continue continue continue continue continue continue vp of infrastructure vi admin

can you clarify your customer’s needs? now that you have uncovered the problems at fleming elevators, use solution questions to help clarify their needs. continue continue continue continue continue continue vp of infrastructure vi admin

can you clarify your customer’s needs? which of the following statements best captures this customer’s need? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? we can’t afford to spend money on excess storage. we have a strict budget. that would be great, if we could do that without having to overprovision. what if you were able to simplify storage management and allow virtualization admins to provision and manage storage with increased efficiency and performance? right amount of storage capacity without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity without tradeoffs right amount of storage performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs you ask: vp of infrastructure vi admin always having enough storage capacity is a big challenge for this customer, but they are also concerned with performance. try again try again try again try again try again this customer has been struggling with performance issues, but they are also having challenges ensuring the right amount of storage capacity. try again try again try again try again try again yes, this customer is looking for both the right amount of storage capacity and the right performance without tradeoffs in either. continue continue continue continue continue

can you clarify your customer’s needs? which of the following statements best captures this customer’s need? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? if storage management could be simplified to the point that any it person could manage storage, that would be great. what if you were able to simplify storage management and allow virtualization admins to provision and manage storage with increased efficiency and performance? more virtualization admins more virtualization admins more virtualization admins more virtualization admins more virtualization admins more virtualization admins increased efficiency and performance increased efficiency and performance increased efficiency and performance increased efficiency and performance increased efficiency and performance increased efficiency and performance simplified storage management simplified storage management simplified storage management simplified storage management simplified storage management simplified storage management you ask: vp of infrastructure vi admin having more virtualization administrators would help the customer, but it isn't a cost-effective method. the customer is looking for storage management that is simple enough for any it person to handle. try again try again try again try again try again increased efficiency and performance are the end outcomes that the customer wants to achieve, but they’re looking to fulfill the need for less complex infrastructure in order to get to those outcomes. try again try again try again try again try again yes, simplified storage management best describes the customer need. a simple storage management system will mean that the customer no longer has to rely on specialized skillsets for storage. continue continue continue continue continue

can you clarify your customer’s needs? which of the following statements best captures this customer’s need? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? if we had a solution that could give us great performance without having to buy expensive, specialized storage, that would be great. what if you have a solution that delivers hyper-converged storage as software and runs with standard x86 servers? hyper-converged storage with x86 servers hyper-converged storage with x86 servers hyper-converged storage with x86 servers hyper-converged storage with x86 servers hyper-converged storage with x86 servers hyper-converged storage with x86 servers hyper-converged storage as software hyper-converged storage as software hyper-converged storage as software hyper-converged storage as software hyper-converged storage as software hyper-converged storage as software more x86-based servers more x86-based servers more x86-based servers more x86-based servers more x86-based servers more x86-based servers you ask: vp of infrastructure vi admin yes, hyper-converged storage on x86 servers is what this customer needs—hyper-convergence (which brings greater performance and efficiencies) that can be used on x86 servers (which brings down cost). hyper-convergence alone or x86 servers alone isn’t what this customer requires. continue continue continue continue continue although it’s true that this customer needs their storage to be hyper-converged, they need more than hyper-convergence to address their need for controlling cost. try again try again try again try again try again although x86-based servers would result in less expense for the customer, just buying more servers wouldn’t help their storage situation. try again try again try again try again try again

here are the three problems and needs you uncovered for this customer: now, it’s time to determine which solution would match each set of problems and needs. continue continue continue continue continue continue need 1: right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs need 2: simplified storage management need 3: hyper-converged storage on x86 servers problem 1: slow overall performance problem 2: complexity of traditional infrastructure problem 3: difficulty controlling storage costs vp of infrastructure vi admin

qualification criteria target market segments all verticals for mid-market, commercial, and enterprise customers with 50+ vms (or multiple robo sites) and any vsphere workloads (including business-critical apps, vdi, robo, and disaster recovery). targets: chief technology officer (cto), chief information officer (cio), vp of infrastructure, architects allies: cloud administrator (infrastructure admin), vi admin (it manager target buyers and stakeholders exponential demand for storage capacity complex management that requires specific knowledge and advanced training expensive scaling budgeting and forecasting storage consumption meeting slas for users and applications power and real estate limitations, from data centers to robo key sales triggers external storage or server refresh new initiatives cost-cutting initiatives new vsphere deployment, upgrade, or project requiring shared storage (business-critical apps, virtual desktop infrastructure (vdi), disaster recovery (dr), remote office/branch office (robo)) concerns about data security problem with current shared storage (performance, capacity, and so on.) pain points is the customer looking to reduce their it costs? does the customer plan a hardware refresh (storage/compute)? has the customer had major issues with their storage? is the customer renewing their vmware ela or planning to have one? is the customer looking to change its it operations into a more cloud-like, services-based model? has the customer bought into hci/sddc? indicators of buying propensity

read/write ssd caching storage policy-based management distributed raid vsphere distributed switch vsan snapshots and clones rack awareness replication (5 min rpo) all-flash support block access (iscsi) qos - iops deduplication and compression (all-flash only) erasure coding (all-flash only) stretched cluster with local failure protection data-at-rest encryption features existing feature in vsan 6.5 new feature in vsan 6.6 vsan 6.6 pricing and packaging summary vsan std vsan adv vsan ent

tco comparison over 5 years for deployment of 20tb all-flash using list prices vsan reduces tco by over 50% compared to all-flash arrays $737.8k power and cooling ($682 per tb) labor (26% of storage cost every year) hardware support (8% of storage cost every year) hardware $68k $322k $99k $248k new expense 50% savings 67% savings 90% savings 65% savings $40k $32k $34k $106k $9.7k $86.5k software support (based on 25% of license cost per year) software (8 vsan advanced licenses) power and cooling ($341 per tb) labor (17.3% of storage cost every year) hardware support (based on dell af6 series) hardware (4 nodes, based on dell af6 series) all-flash traditional storage labor costs based on gartner's it key metrics data 2016 report hardware support based on esg review power and cooling based on wikibon netapp tool vsan taneja group: labor will be 2/3rd cheaper than traditional storage power and cooling assumed to be 50% cheaper in power and cooling compared to traditional storage savings with vsan 58% next next next next next next $308.5k vsan is easier to manage than traditional storage provisioning workloads using traditional storage: lob storage admin vi admin storage admin storage admin vi admin vi admin 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 request for app provisioning opens a ticket to request storage returns lun id to vi admin applies data services to lun creates a lun creates a datastore provisions vms provisioning workloads vsan: lob 1 request for app provisioning vi admin 2 provisions vms with required storage policy next next next next next next back back back back back back bust the myths against all-flash competitors 1 3 4 2 an all-flash solution can achieve higher throughput than vsan because it’s a dedicated hardware. an all-flash solution has better deduplication and compression. with an all-flash solution compute and storage can scale up independently of each other. with an all-flash solution customers can use whichever hypervisor they prefer. vsan has 100k iops per node, which is enough for the vast majority of business applications. why pay more for a capability that is not needed. vsan has 59% lower tco than all-flash dedicated solutions. scaling a dedicated storage solution is more expensive than adding more drives to a server or buying more x86 servers. 70%-80% of workloads already run on vsphere. additionally, with vsphere virtual volumes, vsphere is the only hypervisor that extends spbm to traditional storage. performance efficiency scaling up hypervisor back back back back back back

vsan costs less and is more efficient than nutanix reduce tco by 57% for all-flash tco comparison over 3 years for deployment 4-node all-flash clusters $340k software support hardware $223k $72k $45k 29% savings 59% savings 61% savings savings with vsan 57% $32k $24k $86.5k 4-node nutanix all-flash 4-node vsan all-flash 8 1 12.5%* for every 8 nutanix hosts, there is a need for 1 additional host dedicated to management, resulting in a 12.5% cvm “tax.” every “costs” nutanix hosts host for management cvm 8 vcpus32 gb vramruns on every host nutanix enterprise cloud platform cvm nutanix prism networking nutanix storage acropolis nutanix controller vm (cvm) tax *based on hosts with 32 cpu cores & 256 gb ram nutanix cvm reserves 32 gb ram for dedupe & compression cvm tax $147.7k software $5.2k sw support hw support hardware

customer profiles for hci solutions powered by vmware hyper-converged software vsan ready nodes start with vxrail if: your customer is looking for an appliance-type experience your customer wants enhanced lifecycle management your customer prioritizes deployment speed over deployment flexibility start with vsan ready node if: your customer prefers to use the server vendor of their choice your customer wants more choice in configuration, licensing, and support your customer prioritizes deployment flexibility over deployment speed dell emc vxrail appliance

i presentation in progress… you moved into the presentation room at fleming elevators with your contacts—anja, vi admin, and chinh, vp of infrastructure. you are ready to share your knowledge and expertise with them. continue continue continue continue continue continue vi admin vp of infrastructure

vi admin vp of infrastructure which solution do you want to present to the customer for their problem: right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? enterprise availability elastic scaling of performance tiered all-flash and hybrid options try again try again try again try again try again try again tip: the customer mentioned that it’s important for them to avoid overprovisioning. i problem: right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs problem: complexity of traditional infrastructure which solution do you want to present to the customer for their next problem: complexity of traditional infrastructure? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? policy-based automation single, hyper-converged software stack new deployment options: vxrail and vsan ready node try again try again try again try again try again try again problem: difficulty controlling storage costs which solution do you want to present to the customer for their final problem: difficulty controlling storage costs? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? vsan simplifies storage expanded business-critical applications support server-side economics try again try again try again try again try again try again vsan – enterprise availability vp of infrastructure vsphere and vsan set “failures to tolerate” for high availability vsan provides rack awareness allowing for full rack failures through smart placement mechanism easily add a second site to stretch your vsan cluster between sites deliver zero-minute rpo maximize protection by replicating to a third site with or without site recovery manager return return return return return return availability is important, but it isn’t as much of an issue for us. we really want to resolve the issue of performance, but in a cost-effective way. hci powered by vsan traditional san scales on demand: predictably and cost-effectively we can get our needs met and comply with our strict budget. continue continue continue continue continue continue yes, it would be great to have elastic scaling. we would love to be able to scale out or scale up in a granular fashion, instead of buying large amounts of storage to make sure our needs are covered. vp of infrastructure large upfront purchase storage only costs initial $ scale with full system complex planning small upfront costs includes storage and compute initial $ scale with single node predictable outcome capex i’m sure that these storage options will make things run faster and be more efficient. but eventually, our vdi needs will increase and we’ll still run into bottlenecks. return return return return return return tiered all-flash and hybrid options vp of infrastructure all-flash writes cached first, reads from capacity tier capacity tier flash devices reads primarily from capacity tier 100k iops per host + sub-millisecond latency hybrid read and write cache capacity tier sas / nl-sas / sata 40k iops per host vsan vp of infrastructure return return return return return return that’s a very important feature that helps with performance, but it doesn’t really address the complexity issue that we’re looking at here. efficiency of a single, hyper-converged software stack vp of infrastructure x overhead of virtual appliance x long data paths x bolted-on integration kernel-embedded for optimized i/o data path major advantage in resource utilization 2x cpu efficiency and 3x memory efficiency all features work natively native vmotion and drs vsphere + vsan vsphere storage vm yes, if we could turn storage management into sets of automated policies, that would greatly simplify things. accelerate day-to-day tasks with policy-based automation vp of infrastructure no more luns and volumes! that’s awesome. it’s a headache to configure and maintain all those luns. continue continue continue continue continue continue define granular storage policies storage policies vm / vmdk policy profile policy value availability ftt = 2 capacity reservation space-efficient iops limits 40g 1000 policy gold vsphere vsan managed by vcenter policies automatically applied server cluster simplicity of per-vm storage policies for capacity, performance, and availability no lun/volumes – automated controlof service levels scalable automation platform with powercli non-disruptivepolicy changes certainly, these options make deployment and scaling simpler. but easier deployment doesn’t address our day-to-day need for simpler storage administration. return return return return return return remove complexity with new deployment options eliminate hardware-lock in and choose a solution that matches your needs and skillsets vp of infrastructure turnkey hci appliance from emc and vmware with flexible configurations certified x86 hardware from major server vendors with pre-install options start small – scale on demand simplified lifecycle management configurations to match any use case appliance support experience pre-certified, ready-to-run hardware use existing server vendor and knowledge options for pre-installed software flexible licensing and support v this seems to apply more to the issue of complexity. what we want to see is something that deals more directly with the issue of cost. vsan simplifies storage return return return return return return vp of infrastructure if you know vsphere, you know vsan. performance, scale, and availability for any application vp of infrastructure expanded business-critical applications support sap core ready sap hana enabled tested and validated deployments data locality specific for vdi bundles vsan licenses for lowest cost vdi storage oracle rac ready tested and validated deployments reference architecture papers it’s great that you’re solution supports business-critical applications, that support is something we need. but this doesn’t relate very much to the matter of cost. return return return return return return reduce capex with server-side economics vp of infrastructure look at those other advantages too: no more fibre-channel, smaller footprint, lower capex and opex. this is exactly the kind of economic alternative that we need. continue continue continue continue continue continue those numbers show big savings by using x86 server storage. traditional storage enterprise disks (hdds) $1.25/gb* flash (ssds) $6.30/gb* networking $1356/port $0.69/gb $1.60/gb $513/port server storage pay less for server-side components consolidate onto a smaller footprint lower capex and opex eliminate fibre-channelnetworking now, it’s time to present real-life customer references. continue continue continue continue continue continue solution 1: elastic scaling solution 2: policy-based automation solution 3: server-side economics here are the three solutions that you presented for the customer’s problems and needs: need 1: right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs need 2: simplified storage management need 3: hyper-converged storage on x86 servers problem 1: slow overall performance problem 2: complexity of traditional infrastructure problem 3: difficulty controlling storage costs

we’ve seen some interesting features here, but do you have some case studies with companies like ours? hyper-converged software continue continue continue continue continue continue vi admin vp of infrastructure

vsan accelerates patient care utilizing vsan resulted in massive efficiencies, higher-performance, and simpler scalability vp of infrastructure union hospital deployed a vsan cluster for less than $1 million with hardware, software, services, and maintenance included. they moved a lot of data off their legacy san, which allowed that san to perform better. and they still had many servers’ worth of capacity for future growth. continue continue continue continue continue continue as you can see from the slide, they attained much lower latency and 50 times more i/o throughput. so they got the right amount of storage capacity and performance without tradeoffs and within budget. vi admin 6x <1ms $$ latency is ~ 200x lower than previous system budget-friendly scaling enabled new projects on vsan with over 50% cost savings © 2017 vmware inc. all rights reserved. confidential – not for distribution faster report completion and super fast app and database response times my first customer reference, union hospital in the u.s state of indiana, touches on the performance problems that you are experiencing. union hospital was expanding rapidly, adding a new wing and many regional clinics. but their existing san was already at full capacity. as a result, their storage was performing poorly, just like yours. their legacy vendor recommended that they upgrade all their san hardware and purchase a second san for a total cost of $2 million. this was well beyond budget. union hospital tried out an evaluation version of vsan instead. vsan performed well, and they loved the ease and simplicity. you say:

200 times less latency is a big difference. i’d like to see that kind of impact in our environment. vsan accelerates patient care utilizing vsan resulted in massive efficiencies, higher-performance, and simpler scalability © 2017 vmware inc. all rights reserved. confidential – not for distribution it’s great to achieve that impact without having to spend so much money buying and installing a whole new external storage array. continue continue continue continue continue continue faster report completion and super fast app and database response times latency is ~ 200x lower than previous system budget-friendly scaling enabled new projects on vsan with over 50% cost savings 6x <1ms $$ vp of infrastructure vi admin

my second customer reference is amway. amway is a top 30 forbes private retail company that operates in over 100 countries. they have an it environment with over 4,000 vms. they are using vsan for breadth of critical applications, including line-of-business databases, vdi environment and powering shared storage at branch offices. you say: as a result of vsan-based infrastructure, they have simplified daily management and have had a chance to reorganize teams so that a single team can look after compute, storage, and networking. continue continue continue continue continue continue in addition, they were able to accelerate their move to flash with affordable all-flash thanks to server-side economics, which has resulted in 80% cost savings. vp of infrastructure vi admin global direct-selling giant chooses vsan for tier-1 apps: databases to vdi mix of all-flash and hybrid use cases on vsan greater cost savings versus traditional systems performance improvement reduces launch times from 20min to <1min simpler daily management shifts it focus to strategic projects 80% 20x simple

implementing vsan could allow us to consolidate our compute, storage, and network teams, just as it did at amway. the 80% cost saving is very impressive. continue continue continue continue continue continue vp of infrastructure vi admin global direct-selling giant chooses vsan for tier-1 apps: databases to vdi mix of all-flash and hybrid use cases on vsan greater cost savings versus traditional systems performance improvement reduces launch times from 20min to <1min simpler daily management shifts it focus to strategic projects 80% 20x simple

faster time to market for new products my final customer reference, igov technologies, is a tactical systems integrator. the u.s. federal government asked igov to build a new version of a tactical network platform so that it would be much smaller, lighter, and more powerful than its current version. you say: vsan revolutionizes military computing system implementing vsan greatly increased the portability of a tactical mobile computing system. continue continue continue continue continue continue by replacing network-attached storage modules with server-attached storage virtualized by vsan, igov reduced the product’s weight by 75 percent, reduced the build time 90% and improved storage performance by 10 times. vp of infrastructure vi admin the size of the mobile system was reduced by 85% and its weight by 75%. 75% build time was reduced from 9 hours to 25 minutes. 90% iops (input/output per second) was 10x faster than the previous storage solution. 10x © 2017 vmware inc. all rights reserved. confidential – not for distribution

it seems like everyone who uses vsan gets some astronomical savings and performance increases compared to traditional storage. vp of infrastructure vi admin vsan revolutionizes military computing system implementing vsan greatly increased the portability of a tactical mobile computing system. the size of the mobile system was reduced by 85% and its weight by 75%. 75% build time was reduced from 9 hours to 25 minutes. 90% iops (input/output per second) was 10x faster than the previous storage solution. 10x © 2017 vmware inc. all rights reserved. confidential – not for distribution yes. i definitely think vsan is worth considering. continue continue continue continue continue continue

vi admin vp of infrastructure real customers, real benefits significantly lower costs drastically increased performance simple day-to-day management all the benefits of hyper-converged infrastructure, just by adding vsan. you say: we’ve seen three real customers with the same problems that you’re facing, such as low performance and high storage costs. and we’ve seen how these companies resolved each of those issues and obtained all the benefits of the hyper-converged infrastructure, just by adding vsan to their existing environments. i think this might work for us. and anything that can help in the security side would be great as well. which edition do you think would suit us best? continue continue continue continue continue continue this looks good. vsan is a quick way to get us better performance, and we get big savings as well.

read/write ssd caching storage policy-based management distributed raid vsphere distributed switch vsan snapshots and clones rack awareness replication (5 min rpo) all-flash support block access (iscsi) qos - iops deduplication and compression (all-flash only) erasure coding (all-flash only) stretched cluster with local failure protection data-at-rest encryption vp of infrastructure vi admin features existing feature in vsan 6.5 new feature in vsan 6.6 vsan 6.6 pricing and packaging summary vsan std vsan adv vsan ent i see that the other editions have all-flash capability but standard doesn’t. all-flash hardware would make the overall cost less expensive for us, so we really need that capability. return return return return return return i agree that vsan enterprise looks like the best choice. we want something that comes pre-configured, if possible. continue continue continue continue continue continue yes, this edition looks like the one for us. it has all the features we want, including encryption. we won’t have to worry about self-encrypting drives and individual keys anymore. this version has almost all the features we want, but it doesn’t address any of the security concerns we have. return return return return return return based on this customer’s need, which edition would you recommend? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? vsan standard vsan advanced vsan enterprise try again try again try again try again try again try again enlarge editions slide enlarge editions slide enlarge editions slide enlarge editions slide enlarge editions slide enlarge editions slide tip: this customer wants the best performance, the most storage capacity, and the least storage maintenance they can get. they also want something that can help them address their ongoing security concerns. i

vp of infrastructure vi admin control hci deployments with choice of diy or appliances dell emc vxrail appliances all-in-one hci appliance dell emc best-in-breed data protection rapid time-to-value with multiple configurations single, pro-active vendor support for software and hardware vmware vsan readynodes fully customizable hci choice of 5x more server vendors software and support flexibility backup agnostic to minimize change vp of infrastructure continue continue continue continue continue continue yes, i definitely like the ability to configure it to our preferences. if we can get a ready node already pre-configured with vsan advanced, that would be excellent. we need more configurability than what this appliance offers to us. return return return return return return based on this customer’s need, which deployment option would you recommend? submit submit submit submit submit submit ? vsan ready nodes vxrail appliance try again try again try again try again try again try again tip: this customer is focused on ease of use. this customer would like flexibility in choosing their storage configurations and licenses. i see vsan ready nodes/vxrail customer profiles see vsan ready nodes/vxrail customer profiles see vsan ready nodes/vxrail customer profiles see vsan ready nodes/vxrail customer profiles see vsan ready nodes/vxrail customer profiles see vsan ready nodes/vxrail customer profiles

cio vi admin check resources check resources check resources meeting in progress… henry, the cio of fleming elevators, and anja, their vi admin, join you in the conference room. henry would like to ask you a few questions about the vmware solution. continue continue continue continue continue continue ? how should you respond? just think of it as virtualized storage. you know it’s great for virtualization; it’s also great providing virtual storage solutions. vmware has worked on vsan for over 5 years, with more than 8,000 customers. vmware is just as well known for storage as it is for virtualization. submit submit submit submit submit submit vmware is known for virtualization, but not so much for storage. i don’t know if i want to trust it as my storage solution. return return return return return return hyper-converged architecture isn’t exactly the same as virtualized storage… return return return return return return i don’t think so. also, vmware has a long history in the storage space, and it has a reputation for reliability throughout its solutions. you add: that makes sense. continue continue continue continue continue continue ? how should you respond? actually, vsan has 100k iops per node, which is enough for the vast majority of business applications. why pay more for something you don’t need? actually, vsan has 100k iops, which is much more than what dedicated hardware can achieve. why pay more for getting less? actually, that may be true, but vsan is much easier to manage than traditional storage. and vsan has 59% lower tco than all-flash dedicated solutions. submit submit submit submit submit submit i think a dedicated, all-flash storage solution is better than vsan. we can achieve better performance because it's dedicated hardware. hmm, that’s interesting. continue continue continue continue continue continue and you get that great performance at a much better value than dedicated storage. vsan has 59% lower total cost of ownership than all-flash dedicated solutions. and vsan is a lot easier to manage. with traditional storage, you have at least seven steps to get an app provisioned. with vsan, it's just two steps - the line of business requests the app provisioning, and the vi admin provisions the vms with the required storage policy. you add: vsan vs. traditional storage vsan vs. traditional storage vsan vs. traditional storage vsan vs. traditional storage vsan vs. traditional storage vsan vs. traditional storage that’s not the case. dedicated hardware can get faster performance. return return return return return return performance is an important consideration for us as well. return return return return return return better ha and disaster recovery by deploying in the cloud? i don’t believe that’s the case. return return return return return return ? how should you respond? we can lower the overall costs of vsan by including it in an extended license agreement. vsan is by far the better value, offering many features other solutions don’t have. when you compare the required components, vsan is up to 50% less expensive than competitors. submit submit submit submit submit submit if we choose hyper-converged infrastructure, i’m not sure if vsan would be the right choice for us. there are storage solutions at a lower cost that we could consider, like nutanix. that sounds good. continue continue continue continue continue continue we did a specific study that i can show you in which vsan resulted in 57% less tco than nutanix. you add: vsan vs. nutanix study vsan vs. nutanix study vsan vs. nutanix study vsan vs. nutanix study vsan vs. nutanix study vsan vs. nutanix study i’m not interested in getting an ela right now. return return return return return return that may be true, but cost is a big issue for us. return return return return return return ? how should you respond? let me set you up for an on-demand, hands-on lab that is free and will give you first-hand experience in vsan. let me get some details about your environment right now and we can go through the tco calculator so that you can see your total cost of ownership. let me show you how to download a 60-day free evaluation. submit submit submit submit submit submit let me get vsan assessment running on your system for a week, and that will tell us all the sizing and tco information that you need. you’ve proved your point about vsan being less expensive than the other options. we’re interested in your solution, but we would like to see more. what is the next step? next steps: after showing the analysis to the customer… i don’t have time to go through a lab. return return return return return return i don’t have time right now to give you all that information. return return return return return return we’re in the middle of some major projects and we don’t have time right now to set up a demo environment. return return return return return return that sounds like a great idea. continue continue continue continue continue continue
1 week later… after running vsan assessment and analyzing the results in the tco and sizing calculator, fleming elevators purchased vsan ready nodes and began migrating their infrastructure.

after 6 months, fleming elevators migrated their entire infrastructure from their aging external storage array to a new hci solution composed of vsan ready nodes. immediately, they saw a major impact on performance. reporting request time went from 30 minutes down to 5 minutes, while database latency went from 200 ms to less than 1 ms. as a result of the major performance improvements, productivity increased throughout the organization.

storage maintenance became easy enough for any of the it staff to perform, freeing the storage experts from all the time that they had been taking to perform storage-related tasks. these experts were able to apply their technical expertise to strategic projects and innovation that contributed to producing more revenue for fleming elevators. fleming elevators
henry firth cio fleming elevators over the next two years, we saw our storage costs drop significantly, and we were able to reinvest those savings in strategic initiatives.

the implementation of vrealize suite has been a great success at griswold cruise lines, thanks to your participation in the sale with vmware hci, fleming elevators has obtained the full benefits of hyper-converged infrastructure. your participation in this sale has been crucial to their success.

the details: select the best prospect: all of these customers are possible vmware hci prospects. choose which one would be the best of the group. reynolds college locations: reynolds college is a state college located in kansas city, kansas with nine campuses and thirty one outreach centers located throughout jackson, clay, cass, and platte counties. employees: 3,600 endowment: $445 million software: horizon standard (100 desktops), which includes vsphere desktop and vcenter desktop initiatives: with limited budget, it is looking for solutions to a difficult vdi situation. their storage is overburdened by vdi workload, to the point that user login can take over 20 minutes and recomposing the vdi environment takes more than 10 hours. fleming elevators locations: manufacturing plants at rolla (missouri, usa), mexico city, amsterdam, with 22 distributors and supply centers employees: 10,000+ revenue: $1.1 billion annually software: vcloud suite standard (220 vms), which includes vsphere and vcenter server initiatives: it is looking for an infrastructure solution that is simpler and less expensive, but powerful. their highly-skilled storage personnel spend too much time in the day-to-day operations. now they are opening another manufacturing plant and they need to replace outdated infrastructure. they also have continuing concerns about security. glendale sciences locations: headquartered in the city of glendale, california, glendale sciences has 32 offices and medical manufacturing plants throughout north america, europe, and australia. employees: 7,800 revenue: $32 billion annually software: mirantis openstack (383 vms) initiatives: it has been experiencing increasing complexity with the open source platform that the company is using, and costs have been growing as a result. they want to find a solution that will simplify their storage infrastructure without having to change from their existing platform. brook warehousing locations: headquartered in van horn, texas, brook warehousing operates and administers 13 sites throughout the u.s. employees: 103 revenue: $48 million annually software: vsphere (21 vms), vcenter server initiatives: with growing costs and inefficiencies coming from their storage infrastructure, it is evaluating all-flash and hyper-converged solutions for their main data center at their headquarters. feedback: this is a very good upsell prospect, because horizon advanced and enterprise editions will provide them both additional vdi features and hyper-converged infrastructure. they’re looking for something to resolve their infrastructure’s slow performance, one of the main pain points addressed by vmware hci. but another prospect on the list would represent a greater sales opportunity than this one. feedback: this is the best prospect out of the four in the list. this customer has one of the most prominent storage infrastructure pain points: complexity. vsan definitely fits well as a solution to the customer’s challenge, meeting the need for simplicity and high performance. once vsan is implemented, it staff will no longer be required to have complex storage skillsets. it engineers will have more time to work on innovation and strategic projects. and vsan provides storage with native security through data-at-rest encryption. this encryption is completely software-defined and hardware-agnostic, allowing customers to deploy the hardware of their choice while addressing the security needs of their environment. begin meeting begin meeting begin meeting begin meeting begin meeting begin meeting feedback: this might be a good opportunity for vmware hci, which would greatly simplify the complexity that this customer must be dealing with in their open-source platform. however, the customer would need to move everything over from their current platform to vmware hci, abandoning their current solution. although this sales play might lead to a very profitable deal, this company has expressed that they do not want to change their platform. therefore, another prospect on the list might represent a better opportunity. feedback: this is a very good opportunity for vmware hci, because they already have vsphere/vcenter server and all they need is vsan to attain the benefits of hyper-converged infrastructure. however, with an annual revenue of only $48 million and only 21 vms, this prospect is at the lower end of the scale of vsphere deployments and is potentially used to cheaper, lower-end storage. as a result of being on this lower end, the customer would have to value the benefits of vsan enough to outweigh storage expense that may be greater than what they’re accustomed to. this higher expense creates more of a challenge for selling vsan to this customer. please view the details for each of the four customers before selecting the best prospect. you have not viewed the details for all of the four leads.

Congratulations, you have finished the VSP Hyper-Converged Infrastructure e-learning. Now that you’ve successfully completed this e-learning, you should be able to take advantage of the big storage shift to hyper-converged technology by selling VMware Hyper-Converged Software. You should now know how to qualify your customers for VMware HCS, how to position it to customers, and how to respond to any questions and objections they may have. Select here to take the assessment and get credit for taking this competency.
